questions.description: Enjoys being the center of attention and feels reinforced by admiration.
Exaggerates achievements or talents to impress others.
Frequently fantasizes about exceptional success, power, or attractiveness.
Seeks special treatment or exceptions to rules that apply to everyone.
Chooses relationships or groups that elevate status or image.
Feels irritated when not recognized as unique or authoritative.
Looks for frequent reassurance that they are appreciated or admired.
Competes for recognition and constantly compares achievements.
Redirects conversations toward self or personal stories with ease.
Minimizes others' needs if they conflict with personal goals.
Interrupts or overrides others to keep the spotlight.
Feels entitled to others' time or loyalty without reciprocity.
Keeps score of favors or support to leverage later.
Struggles to apologize sincerely when at fault.
Reacts defensively or angrily to even mild feedback.
Uses charm to influence but withdraws when not admired.
Avoids showing vulnerability or asking for help.
Feels empty or flat when not receiving attention or praise.
Feels envy when others achieve and believes they deserved it less.
Thinks others envy them and guards their image carefully.
Holds a sense of superiority over most people.
Blames circumstances or others more than self when mistakes happen.
Relationships strain when others set boundaries or disagree.
Swings between feeling exceptional and fearing not being enough.

carreras.description: Practice acknowledging others' wins and request specific feedback, not only praise. Therapy can help balance validation needs with genuine connection.
Rehearse listening without interrupting, validate others' emotions, and set clear boundaries. Relational or mentalization-focused therapy may help.
Work on tolerating mistakes, reframing criticism as data, and building steadier self-esteem. A clinician can guide regulation and self-compassion strategies.

labels.HeroSubtitle: Not a diagnosis. Use it to notice patterns and decide if you want professional support.
labels.MethodNote: Self-exploration tool. Not diagnostic. Items draw from clinical criteria and psychoeducation guides to support therapeutic conversations.
labels.MethodSummaryScoring: Percent is based on your "yes" responses per dimension; more "yes" means higher perceived frequency.
